Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on July
25, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include
the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's
performance within 30 days of the completion of

the probationary period or within 180 days,
whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee's performance annually thereafter.
One of seven new employee files reviewed did not have a performance
evaluation completed within 180 days of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of
the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform
variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time
between the variable interval checks shall not exceed
f ifteen minutes.
Eight of eight bed check logs reviewed documented bed checks were not
completed at variable interval checks not to exceed 15 minutes.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection Report dated 9/12/23; CAP approved 9/25/23
CCI Rule 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical
examinations.
(2) An institution shall have the following
documentation of an admission physical examination
for each resident, unless an earlier examination is
m edically indicated:
(b) For a resident 3 years of age or older, a
physical examination shall have been completed
within 1 year prior to admission or a new
physical examination shall be completed within
30 calendar days after admission.
One of three open youth files reviewed had an initial physical completed over 30
days after admission. The youth was admitted on 3/11/25 and his initial physical
was completed on 4/16/25.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an initial treatment plan for each resident within 30
c alendar days of admission.
One of three open youth files reviewed did not have an initial treatment plan
completed within 30 calendar days of admission. Youth was admitted on 3/11/25
and his plan was completed on 4/11/25, which is 31 days.

Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection Report dated 9/12/23; CAP approved 9/25/23
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; updated treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an updated treatment plan for each resident at
least once every 90-calendar days following the initial
t reatment plan.
Three of three open youth files reviewed did not have updated treatment plans
completed within 90 days following the initial treatment plan. One youth's initial
treatment plan ended 4/11/25, and as of 7/25/25, an updated treatment plan had
not yet been completed. Another youth's treatment plan was dated 1/10/25-
4/11/25, which is 91 days. It should be noted this UTP overlapped the date of
1/10/25 with the youth's ITP. The third youth had two overdue updated treatment
plans. One was dated 9/5/24-12/5/24 (91 days), and the date of 9/5/24
overlapped with the previous UTP. The second updated treatment plan was dated
3/5/25-6/5/25 (92 days), and the date of 3/5/25 overlapped with the previous UTP.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of
the services provided while in residence,
including medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident's needs that
remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the
facility after discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental
follow up that is needed, have been reviewed
with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
Two of two closed youth files reviewed did not include the information contained
in subsections (b-e) of the rule.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The start date of the updated treatment plan should be one day after the end
date of the previous treatment plan. Overlapping dates were the cause of some
of the facility's updated treatment plans being overdue.
• When using a date calculator to determine due dates for treatment plans, the
facility should use 29 days and 89 days instead of 30 days and 90 days to ensure
reports do not go overdue.
• The electronic system staff are using to enter bed checks does not seem to be
efficient as there were multiple bed checks completed over 15 minutes. In talking
with the facility, staff reported they complete bed checks, then have to enter the
bed checks in the computer and by the time they do that, it's time for another bed
check. The facility should consider getting a tablet so staff can walk around with
the tablet and enter bed checks in real time.
• The facility must create and follow a uniform process for employee records to
ensure all the information required by licensing rules is in the employee's file,
especially at the time of the facility's annual audit. The electronic files provided by
HR were missing multiple documents. The HR file can come from the program
directly or HR, but the file provided must include all required documents.
• The facility's case management supervisor was provided instructions regarding
the requirements of discharge plans during another facility's audit in February
2025. The discharge plans reviewed in this audit were missing the required
information, which was discussed again with the case management supervisor
during the on-site visit.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require or request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
facility had one CAP as a result of their 2024 Interim Audit dated 9/17/24; CAP
approved 10/11/24. The facility had violations for Rule 113(1)(g) and 113(1)(h).
To address the violations, the facility updated their new hire and transfer hire
checklists to include background check requirements and subsequent actions if
criminal convictions are found, required Chief Administrator to sign off on the

checklists prior to hiring staff, held quarterly CAP compliance meetings to review
completed hiring checklists and discuss issues, completed a written assessment
of the employee’s criminal conviction, and received the employee’s written
statement regarding their criminal conviction.
Another CAP was a result of SIR #2025SIC0000198 dated 2/21/25; CAP
approved 3/12/25. The facility had a violation for Rule 109(1)(c) due to a previous
staff admitting to violating the facility’s cell phone policy, the same previous staff
admitting to violating the facility’s resident offsite supervision policy, and three
current staff not following the staff code of conduct policy and PSA manual
procedure outlining the steps for mandated reporting. To address the violations,
the facility completed a live mandated reporter training for all staff, completed a
mandatory in-person mandated reporter and staff code of conduct training for all
staff, had staff sign off on policies related to the violation, put the three current
staff on administrative leave, and made a note in the previous staff’s file she
would not be eligible for rehire.
A third CAP was a result of SIR #2025SIC0000297 dated 2/21/25; CAP approved
3/12/25. The facility had a repeat violation for Rule 109(1)(c) due to a staff
violating the facility’s cell phone policy. To address the violation, the facility
placed the staff on administrative leave during the investigation, had the staff sign
the cell phone policy again in front of the branch director, the branch director
issued the staff a written warning, and required all staff to complete the “Mobile
Communication Device Use for Agency Business” training annually.
Financial Overview
The facility's budget and financial audit were reviewed, and there were no financial
concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported the program continues to have quarterly CAP
meetings with the treatment team which includes the quality assurance team,
program director, program supervisor, and clinical supervisor as they all complete
the hiring process. In addition, the quality assurance team has also worked on the
new hire coversheet and transfer hire coversheet to ensure the program stays in
compliance. The additions and changes to these coversheets have had a positive
impact on the hiring process.

Staff and Youth Interviews
One supervisor reported they have a good team, they work together well, and they
communicate well. She reported the new program director has been good for the
program, especially regarding holding staff and youth more accountable. She
reported the youth have responded well to having a more standard point system
established for behaviors and expectations, which was something the new
program director implemented. She reported she has felt more supported in her
role and has had more of a voice since the Branch Director became her direct
supervisor. She reported being the case management supervisor for three different
programs is a lot, so she hopes another solution is found for one program so she
can keep the other two similar programs.
Another supervisor reported there is a need for more support for and follow-
through from the case management team. He reported he feels more supported in
his role with the new program director in place. He reported the previous program
director’s check-ins would be “hey, how are you?”, while the new program director
has helped support him navigate things with the program to make them less
complicated, more simplified, and more effective. He reported the new program
director is very forward-thinking and checks in with all the youth and staff in the
entire program by having 1:1 meetings. He reported the new program director
changing the points system for the youth has been a great change because it puts
more ownership on the youth rather than the staff and program. He reported
previously staff were deducting points from youth without providing sufficient
explanations, but that’s now changed, and they’re working on being more
consistent and not faulting the youth for staff errors. He reported they’ve been
focusing on working with the youth during treatment team meetings to teach them
to be leaders in the home and be advocates for themselves as well as others. He
reported there’s been a lot of growth and maturity amongst the youth in the
program, which has been great to see. He reported there are multiple job openings
for youth specialists right now. He reported there have been a lot of changes
internally with the screening, hiring and onboarding processes, which has been
more effective in getting qualified and higher quality candidates.
The youth specialist interviewed reported interacting with the youth while doing
outings, walking, riding bikes, doing activities, etc. has been the best part of his
employment. He reported he noticed the youth had certain behaviors when he first
started and he’s seen so much growth in them over the last 9 months, which has
been amazing to witness. He reported they’re working on developing each youth’s
individuality by doing independent outings, learning how to cook, helping increase
their maturity, encouraging participation in extra-curricular activities, etc. He
reported he would like to see increased communication and organization within the
program. For example, if youth have soccer practice on the calendar and it’s
cancelled, the person who found out it was cancelled won’t delete the information
off the calendar or doesn’t update addresses if the locations are changed. He
reported more communication amongst program staff will lead to better support

and more consistency for the youth, so he hopes to see positive changes. He
reported he feels more supported in his role with the new assistant supervisor in
place. He reported the new assistant supervisor is quick to follow-up, takes notes
during 1:1 meetings, and asks good questions, which makes him feel heard. He
reported when he first started as a youth specialist 9 months ago, he doesn’t feel
he was taught properly or guided fully in depth with his job and role, so he makes it
a point to help teach others. He reported he feels comfortable providing feedback
to management if he has any.
Youth reported they like everything at the facility and there’s nothing they don’t
like. They reported staff treat them well, and they don’t have any concerns about
staff. They reported they feel safe at the facility. They reported the food is good
and they get enough food.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility was completed on 7/25/25 and there were no safety
concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
